_header: And when they had received her charge
_description: ‘Why I Can’t Be a Nun’ — in 8-line stanzas

BLCottVesDIX.First Lines:
[177]…And whan they had rasceyved her chargeThey spared nether mud ne myre…
[190]…That…Holy wryt…Pleynely go rede hyt a…And hyt ys wretyn in GenesysIn the fowre and thyrty ChapytellHow dyna for sche bode not styllBut went owte to see thynges in veyneSche was defowled aȝenst her wyllAnd there fore thowsandys of peple were sclaynyowre barbe your wymppyll and your vayleYowre mantell and youre devowte clothyng…
BLCottVesDIX.Last Lines:
[182v]…ffor dreme was hyt none ne fantasyeHyt was vn to me a gracius mene…
[190v]…Seynte sexburge & setnte ErmenyldeOf all these holy women we rede…
BLCottVesDIX.Note: Begins and ends imperfectly; f. 190 misbound. First lines on f. 190 incomplete due to damage to upper outer corner of leaf.
BLCottVesDIX.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James. 
             Early English Poems and Lives of Saints.
Transactions of the London Philological Society
         1858; Pt. 2, Berlin, 1862: 138-50.
